By Valerie Volcovici
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Georgia's two Republican senators broke with members of their party
column2: saying they would consider Supreme Court nominees put forward by Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton if she wins the presidency
column3: the Atlanta Journal-Constitution reported on Sunday.The comments from U.S. Senator Johnny Isakson
column4: who is up for re-election on Tuesday
column5: and U.S. Senator David Perdue came after Republican Senators John McCain and Ted Cruz suggested they might block any of Clinton's potential nominees.""You don't shirk your responsibility when you're an elected official. You sanctify your responsibility
column6: and that's what I'll do. I'll consider who she nominates at the time she does and make a decision that's right for the people of Georgia
column7: Isakson told the Atlanta newspaper.

column1: A spokeswoman for Perdue
column2: a member of the Senate Judiciary Committee
column3: told the AJC: ""He wants to ensure we have a Supreme Court justice who will uphold the Constitution
column4: and he will examine each nominee independently based on their merits.""The death of conservative Justice Antonin Scalia in February has left the nine-member high court short one justice and evenly split between liberals and conservatives.

column1: In March
column2: President Barack Obama nominated Merrick Garland
column3: a federal appeals court judge
column4: to replace Scalia
column5: but the Republican-led Senate has refused to consider the nomination
column6: saying the next president should make the pick.The Senate's inaction on Garland
column7: a centrist
column8: has made the Supreme Court a potent issue in the election. After many years of leaning conservative
column9: the court could tilt to the left for the first time in decades if Clinton wins the election.

column1: Isakson said he expects the Senate will confirm Garland before January in the event of a Clinton victory. Some Republicans fear Clinton would nominate a more liberal justice
column2: swinging the ideological balance of the court even further to the left. (Additional reporting by David Morgan; Editing by Paul Simao)"	['Clinton'

column1: 1	1	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-idUSKBN1300M5	Security hustles Trump from stage after protester displays sign	"
By Emily Stephenson and Amanda Becker
| RENO
column2: Nevada/PHILADELPHIA

column1: RENO
column2: Nevada/PHILADELPHIA Republican Donald Trump was rushed off stage by security agents  at a rally in Reno
column3: Nevada
column4: on Saturday night after a false alarm as someone in the crowd shouted ""gun"" during scuffles with a man who held up a ""Republicans against Trump"" sign.The incident occurred as Trump and Democratic rival  Hillary Clinton crisscrossed the United States a late push to win over undecided voters and make sure supporters turn out enthusiastically on Election Day.Two security agents seized Trump by the shoulders and hustled him backstage as police officers swarmed over a man in the front of the crowd and held him down and searched him before escorting him away with his hands behind his back.Trump
column5: seemingly unruffled
column6: returned to the stage and continued his speech after a short time
column7: saying ""Nobody said it was going to be easy for us"" and adding ""We will never be stopped.""After being released
column8: the man who was apprehended told CBS News Reno affiliate KTVN-2 that he was a Republican supporter who attended the rally to express his opposition to Trump.""I came here with this sign expecting boos ... But it was just a sign
column9: Austyn Crites said. Crites said when he took it out
column10: the crowd began to attack him
column11: choking and beating him before ""someone yelled about a gun.""After being held for a few hours' questioning and security  and background checks
column13: and that the police ""did their job.""Crites said he wanted to contrast President Barack Obama's reaction to a protestor during a rally a few days ago
column14: in which he urged the crowd to respect the protester
column16: saying he wanted ""people to understand"" the difference.""I have  nothing against Trump supporters
column17: Crites told the station. ""We are all registered Republicans and support many of the same candidates for local offices. I have serious concern against Trump
column18: he added.The Secret Service confirmed that the incident erupted when an unidentified individual in front of the stage shouted ""gun.""""Secret Service agents and Reno Police Officers immediately apprehended the subject. Upon a thorough search of the subject and the surrounding area
column20: the Secret Service said in a statement.The incident began when Trump noticed what he considered a heckler. Seconds later people near the stage began pointing at someone in the crowd near the front
column21: and agents took Trump away.In a statement
column23: Reno and Nevada law enforcement for ""their fast and professional response.""

column1: Meantime
column2: in Philadelphia
column3: pop singer Katy Perry performed at a Clinton rally
column4: the latest in a string of celebrity appearances aimed at getting out the vote among millennials.""When your kids and grandkids ask you what you did in 2016
column5: when it was all on the line
column6: I want you be able to say you voted for a better
column7: stronger
column8: America
column9: Clinton said.  Opinion polls show Clinton still holds advantages in states that could be critical in deciding the election. But her lead has narrowed after a revelation a week ago that the Federal Bureau of Investigation was looking into a new trove of emails as part of its probe into her handling of classified information while she was secretary of state.A McClatchy-Marist opinion poll released on Saturday of  voters nationwide showed Clinton leading by 1 percentage point compared to 6 percentage points in September.A Reuters/Ipsos tracking poll on Saturday showed Clinton ahead by 4 percentage points nationally compared to 5 points on Friday
column10: while an ABC News-Washington Post tracking poll had Clinton ahead by 48 to 43 percent.COMPETING FOR FLORIDA VOTES

column1: Both candidates spent time in Florida
column2: considered one of the most hotly contested states. The 2000 presidential election was decided in Florida after a dispute over votes and recounting of ballots went to the U.S. Supreme Court
column3: which ruled in favor of Republican George W. Bush over Democrat Al Gore.

column1: The Real Clear Politics average of Florida opinion polls found Clinton with a lead of about 1 percentage point - indicating the race there is a virtual tie.Trump spoke at a rally on Saturday morning in Tampa
column2: Florida
column3: where he continued to criticize Clinton for supporting the Affordable Care Act
column4: also known as Obamacare
column5: in the wake of an announcement that premiums are going to rise next year.""It's not going to matter because if we win I'm throwing it out anyway
column6: Trump said.Shortly before Clinton took the stage in Pembroke Pines
column7: Florida
column8: rain poured down. People in the crowd waiting for Clinton at the outdoor rally remained in place
column9: taking out umbrellas and fashioning garbage bags into head coverings.""I'm thrilled to be here and boy is this a hardy group
column10: rain or shine you are ready
column12: her voice cracking with hoarseness.She cut her speech short as she became soaked in rain
column14: ""I don't think I need to tell you all of the wrong things about Donald Trump.""At the JFK library in Hialeah
column16: people lined up outside for early voting. Nearby
column17: supporters of both candidates waved signs and shouted slogans
column18: urging passing drivers to honk their horns.

column1: We want someone to come in and clean house
column2: said Cuban-American Ariel Martinez
column4: a Trump supporter.Early voting began in September and the data firm Catalist estimates more than 30 million ballots have been cast in 38 states. There are an estimated 225.8 million eligible U.S. voters. Saturday was the final day for early voting in many Florida counties.CHANGES IN PLANS

column1: Trump and Clinton campaigns adjusted travel schedules for the next two days to states where they saw opportunity.Trump told the crowd in Tampa that there would be a campaign event in Minnesota this weekend
column2: although one had not previously been scheduled. Minnesota has not voted for a Republican since 1984. His campaign confirmed a rally scheduled for Wisconsin on Sunday has been canceled.Clinton started the day by stopping by the West Miami Community Center
column3: a Cuban American neighborhood
column4: with telenovela star Jencarlos Canela
column5: a Miami native of Cuban descent.She then visited her campaign's office in Little Haiti where there is a large concentration of Haitian-American residents. Clinton was joined by Sybrina Fulton
column6: the mother of Trayvon Martin
column7: the unarmed black teenager who was shot dead in 2012 by a Sanford
column8: Florida neighborhood watchman
column9: George Zimmerman.While Trump prefers large-scale rallies
column10: Clinton has filled her campaign schedule with targeted appearances meant to court voters in specific demographics. Cuban voters have historically favored Republicans
column11: but younger generations have shifted toward Democratic Party candidates.In what was seen as an effort to defend typically Democratic turf

column14: before returning to Pennsylvania for a rally in Philadelphia with President Barack Obama and first lady Michelle Obama
column15: and former President Bill Clinton.Trump is to make stops on Sunday in Iowa
column18: Pennsylvania and Virginia to try to steal away some states that have gone Democratic in recent presidential elections. (Story corrects dateline to remove ""N.C."".) (Reporting by Emily Stephenson
column20: and Luciana Lopez; Writing by Steve Holland and Chris Michaud; editing by Grant McCool

column1: 2	2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-latinos-idUSKBN1310YU	Jump in Florida
column2: Nevada early voting could reap Latino gains for Clinton	"

column1: By Luciana Lopez
| MIAMI

MIAMI The man answering a volunteer's knock on the door in the Kendall section of Miami-Dade County on Saturday was emphatic: Not only would he vote but ""esperamos que la presidenta gane"" - Spanish for ""we hope Madam President wins.""Volunteers across Florida made a last-minute push to get voters to the polls this weekend with early voting ending on Sunday ahead of Election Day on Tuesday
column2: pitting Republican Donald Trump against Democrat Hillary Clinton
column3: or ""la presidenta
column4: as the man at the door called her.Latino voters like the man in Kendall and elsewhere could have an outsized influence in Tuesday's election. Early voting data may portend a jump in the number of Hispanic voters this year
column5: especially in the key swing states of Nevada and Florida
column6: and Clinton would likely be the biggest beneficiary.Clinton has polled much stronger among Latino voters nationwide: a Washington Post/Univision poll released last week gave her 67 percent of the Hispanic vote to Trump's 19 percent. Trump has fared poorly with America's largest minority voting group
column7: having repeatedly angered Hispanics with disparaging comments about their communities. A recent poll conducted by the firms The Tarrance Group and Bendixen and Amandi found that Hispanic registered voters in Florida favor Clinton 60 percent to 30 percent. In Nevada the gap was even wider - 72 percent for Clinton and 19 percent for Trump.In Florida
column8: the Clinton campaign estimates early Latino voting is up 139 percent
column9: or more than twice as much
column11: according to a field report dated Wednesday.Democratic strategist Steve Schale
column14: 000 more Hispanics had voted early or by mail as of Wednesday than had voted early or by mail in the entire 2012 election
column15: according to a post on his blog.""And keep in mind
column16: because Hispanic is a self-identifying marker
column17: studies have found that the real Hispanic vote is larger than the registration. So while Hispanics might make up 14.2 percent of the voters who have voted so far
column20: he wrote.Despite the surge in early voting
column21: there is no certainty about which candidate people chose for president. There is also no guarantee that the higher Latino turnout rate will continue on Election Day and that they and other minority voters will make enough of a difference to swing Florida and other states. Trump kicked off his maverick campaign last year by describing Mexican immigrants as rapists and criminals
column22: and made a tough stance on immigration a signature part of his vision for America. He called for a wall to be built on the border and said an American-born federal judge could not do his job because of his Mexican heritage.

column1: That rhetoric might be hurting him in an increasingly diverse Florida
column2: where many election watchers believe Trump must win to have a chance to secure the minimum 270 votes in the Electoral College needed to claim the White House. Daniel Smith
column3: a political science professor at the University of Florida who also does voting research
column4: said Democrats have a strong lead among Hispanics who have voted early in Florida. ""From my perspective this is Hispanics in Florida reacting viscerally to Donald Trump
column5: said Smith. ""His scorched earth campaign against immigrants and especially Hispanics is coming home to roost in Florida.""DEMOCRATIC EDGE IN KEY COUNTY

column1: The state of Nevada does not note race or ethnicity on its voter registration but other data there suggest Latinos also are turning out in force.For one thing
column2: Clark County has seen a surge in early voting. Between in-person and absentee voting
column3: registered Democrats have now returned over 72
column4: 000 more ballots than registered Republicans there. Those figures do not indicate which candidate voters picked
column5: only the party with which the voters are registered.Friday alone saw 57
column6: 172 votes in person in Clark County. Photos making the rounds on social media showed especially long lines at a Cardenas market voting site
column7: which stayed open late to accommodate the surge of voters.Clark County
column8: which includes Las Vegas
column9: has a large Latino population - 30.6 percent
column10: compared to 28.1 percent for Nevada as a whole
column11: according to the U.S. Census.Even more Republican votes elsewhere in the state are so far not enough to counterbalance that Democratic lead in Clark County. Overall
column13: 000 more ballots in Nevada than Republicans.

column1: That's not an accident
column2: said Artie Blanco
column3: the Nevada state coordinator for the progressive group For Our Future. Her organization and others banded together in a major get-out-the-vote push
column4: especially among voters of color
column5: and the coalition's data suggest that the effort paid off.Twenty-two percent of Democrats who voted on Friday had a conversation with someone from that progressive coalition at some point after Oct. 15
column6: Blanco said. Among Latino voters on the last three voting days
column7: the coalition had conversations with 14 percent of them after Oct. 15
column8: according to the group's data.Trump on Saturday took a jab at the early voting turnout in Nevada.""They didn't get the kind of vote that they needed to stop us on Tuesday
column9: Trump said in Reno. ""Tuesday is our day in this state.""He said Reno and northern Nevada could ""carry us all the way to Washington."" But Blanco said the votes were instead the result of major work to bring out voters
column10: especially people of color and that progressive organizations were not done yet.""We have all these voters that we need to now go back and say
column12: '"" she said of those who had not yet cast ballots. (Writing and reporting by Luciana Lopez; Additional reporting by Emily Stephenson; Editing by Bill Trott and Mary Milliken)"	['Trott'

WASHINGTON FBI Director James Comey told Congress on Sunday a recent review of newly discovered emails did not change the agency's conclusion reached in July that no charges were warranted in the case of Hillary Clinton's use of a private email server.U.S. Republican Representative Jason Chaffetz said in a tweet that Comey had informed him of the conclusion. Comey's letter to Congress informing it of the newly discovered emails had thrown Clinton's presidential race against Republican Donald Trump into turmoil.
(Reporting by Alana Wise and John Whitesides; Editing by Paul Simao)"	['Chaffetz'

column1: 4	4	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-intimidation-idUSKBN1310ZF	U.S. appeals court removes new voter-intimidation rules in Ohio	"
By Andy Sullivan
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump won a legal battle on Sunday when a U.S. appeals court in Ohio removed new restrictions on partisan poll watchers that Democrats had sought to prevent Election Day voter intimidation.The rules overturned by the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals would have imposed greater penalties on people who harass voters during Tuesday's election.Voter intimidation already is prohibited under U.S. law but Democrats have pushed for greater restrictions in Ohio and five other battleground states
column2: citing concerns that Trump's heated rhetoric might inspire Election Day chaos.On the campaign trail
column3: Trump has warned the election may be rigged and has called on supporters to keep an eye on voting activity for possible signs of fraud in large cities. Numerous studies have found that U.S. voter fraud is exceedingly rare.

column1: On Friday U.S. District Court Judge James Gwin imposed new restrictions on those who monitor voting activity
column2: saying they may not interrogate voters within 100 feet of a polling place
column3: block them from entering
column4: or photograph them as they come and go. Those found to violate the rules could be held in contempt of court.The Trump campaign had argued that those restrictions were not justified
column5: given that there had been no reported instances of voter harassment in the state so far.

column1: In the end
column2: plaintiff's case rested on rhetoric
column3: not evidence
column4: Trump attorney Chad Readler wrote in a court filing on Saturday.The appeals court sided with Trump
column5: lifting the new rules two days before Election Day. The ruling came before Democrats had a chance to respond to Readler's motion and the party said it may appeal.

column1: We are stunned that a court would rule without even allowing one of the parties to file a memo explaining their case
column2: but that is exactly what the Sixth Circuit has done in this decision. We are exploring our options to reverse this unfortunate ruling
column3: Ohio Democratic Party spokeswoman Kirstin Alvanitakis said.The Trump campaign did not immediately respond to a request for comment. (Reporting by Andy Sullivan; Editing by Bill Trott)"	['Sullivan'
column4: 'Trump']	[]

column1: 5	5	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-registration-idUSKBN1310KJ	Social media helps U.S. millennial voters register
column2: turnout worries linger	"

column1: By Amy Tennery and Melissa Fares
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK As the youngest members of the millennial generation became old enough to vote in this year's U.S. presidential election
column2: states and social media platforms poured efforts into online registration
column3: hoping to attract these tech savvy voters who now rival Baby Boomers as the country's largest demographic.With Election Day just two days away
column4: political experts are skeptical that a record number of millennials who signed up to vote will actually result in the 18-34 year-old age group turning out at the polls in proportion to their relative size of the U.S. population.Millennials make up approximately 31 percent of U.S. citizens eligible to vote
column5: according to the Pew Research Center
column6: on par for the first time with Baby Boomers
column7: who are typically aged 52-70 years old. There are an estimated 225.8 million eligible U.S. voters.  Millennials have so far
column8: however
column9: turned out in much lower numbers in elections than Baby Boomers. In 2008
column10: a record year for millennial turnout
column11: just 50 per cent of those eligible to vote did so
column12: the National Census Bureau said. That compared with turnout rates of 69 per cent for Baby Boomers and 61 percent for people aged 36 to 51
column13: also known as Generation X.This year
column14: a number of efforts on social media by states and non-profits aimed to change that
column15: including Facebook reminders on users' accounts
column17: celebrities creating Snapchat and an Instagram post urging people to vote.According to a survey of state electoral officials and voter non-profits around the United States
column18: these social media campaigns have paid off
column19: at least when it came to getting young voters registered. A survey of 2
column20: 000 millennials conducted by social media platform Yik Yak
column21: which is known for its popularity among college students and teens
column22: showed that 62 percent registered to vote for the first time this year and
column24: 9 percent registered online following a social media prompt.In California
column25: roughly 31 per cent of all registered voters are now aged 18-35. A Facebook reminder on May 16 coincided with 143
column26: 255 people registering or updating their registrations online that day in the state
column29: said California Secretary of State spokesman Sam Mahood. Other states reported similar spikes.

column1: In Oregon
column2: more than 420
column3: 000 people registered to vote online in 2016
column4: up from 2012 when 163
column5: 545 used the online system. Digital voter enrollments in Washington jumped by roughly 135
column7: compared to 2012. From January through mid-October this year
column9: 318 people used the online system in Indiana
column10: nearly three times as many as in 2012. ""Let's face it - that's where [younger voters] are; they're on social media
column12: the secretary of state for Connecticut
column14: including a dedicated hashtag and Facebook's banner ads
column16: we're having pretty dramatic results.""'HUGE POTENTIAL'

column1: Like a lot of experts
column2: Donald Green
column3: a professor of political science at Columbia University
column4: is skeptical that an increase in young voter registration will correspond with millennials unseating the Baby Boomers as the most active voting bloc.

column1: Green conceded that there was ""change afoot
column2: but said he thought it would far more gradual. By his estimate
column3: it would be  25 years before millennials overtake Baby Boomers
column4: or what he dubbed ""generational replacement.""""In presidential elections the translation of new registration to votes is more like one half or one third
column5: he said.Michael Cornfield
column6: an associate professor of political management at George Washington University
column7: agreed that registering someone to vote does not guarantee they'll show up on Election Day.""It's up to the campaigns to do the last bit
column8: which is to say make sure the right millennials in the right battleground states are being targeted

column1: Some political experts said that
column2: in general
column3: millennials tend to vote more for Democratic Party candidates than Republicans.Laura Wray-Lake
column4: an assistant professor at the University of California-Los Angeles
column5: said the increase in millennial registration could be a boon for Democrats if they could harness some of the social media techniques used to register voters to get them to the polls. With many political experts expecting overall voter turnout to be lower this year
column6: millennial voters in swing states are a bloc that Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton could hope to turn out. Clinton leads Republican candidate Donald Trump by 27 percentage points among likely voters ages 18-34
column7: according to a Reuters/Ipsos poll.""Young people have huge potential for political impact"" Wray-Lake said. ""I think eventually these millennials will be deciding the future of the country.""For a graphic on Online voter registration
column8: click tmsnrt.rs/2fjdh4j (Reporting By Amy Tennery; editing by Grant McCool)"	['Clinton'

column1: 6	6	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-poll-nbc-idUSKBN1310QC	NBC-Wall Street Journal poll has Clinton leading Trump by four points	"

WASHINGTON Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton holds a four-point lead over Republican Donald Trump in the final NBC-Wall Street Journal poll released on Sunday.The NBC-Wall Street Journal poll showed Clinton leading Trump by 44 percent to 40 percent. Libertarian Gary Johnson was at 6 percent and Green Party Candidate Jill Stein had 2 percent.Clinton's lead shrank from 11 points over Trump the last time the poll was conducted in mid-October
column2: before the FBI said it was reviewing new emails in its investigation of the former secretary of state.

column1: The poll also showed Clinton with a 12 percentage point lead over Trump - 51 percent to 39 percent - among people who have said they have voted early.
(Reporting By Valerie Volcovici; Editing by Bill Trott)"	['Clinton'

WASHINGTON Republican vice presidential candidate Mike Pence on Sunday pledged Donald Trump's campaign would accept a ""clear outcome"" to the U.S. presidential election but said both campaigns reserved legal options if there was a disputed result.""The campaign has made it very clear that a clear outcome
column2: obviously
column3: both sides will accept. But I think both campaigns have also been very clear that in the event of disputed results
column4: they reserve all rights and remedies
column5: Pence said in an interview on ""Fox News Sunday.""

column1: (Reporting By Caren Bohan; Editing by Bill Trott)"	['Pence']	[]
8	8	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-profile-idUSKBN1310KA	Amid scandal
column2: bluster and insults
column3: Trump closes in on White House	"

column1: By Bill Trott
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Supercharging the bluster
column2: hyperbole and media mastery that made him one of the world's best-known businessmen
column3: Donald Trump upended U.S. democratic traditions on a 17-month quest he hopes will lead to the White House.       From his grand Trump Tower escalator entrance into the Republican presidential race on June 16
column5: Trump managed to be simultaneously charismatic and combative
column6: elitist and populist
column7: lewd and pious as he drilled into a lode of polarity and anti-Washington anger among American voters. In Tuesday's election against Democrat Hillary Clinton
column8: Trump is making his first run for public office. Trump called it a movement
column9: not a campaign.He drew enthusiastic crowds to rallies where people cheered him for ""just saying what everybody's thinking."" Critics  labeled him misogynistic
column15: a demagogue and a sexual predator
column16: all accusations he denied.It took Trump
column18: little more than 10 months to vanquish 16 other candidates and become the first major party nominee since General Dwight Eisenhower in the 1950s to have no government experience. He drew a record number of votes in primary contests but in so doing created a rift in the party.  Then he squared off against Clinton
column20: in a race marked by controversies that included upheaval in his staff
column24: that Clinton and the media had rigged the election against him.He shocked many by saying he might not accept the election result if he lost
column25: repudiating a U.S. tradition of peaceful government transition. He said that as president he would investigate Clinton for her use of email while secretary of state. He vowed to send her to jail.His campaign took a scandalous turn in October with the release of a 2005 video in which Trump
column27: told a television entertainment reporter that he liked to kiss women without invitation and that
column28: because he was rich and famous
column29: he could ""grab them"" by the genitals without recriminations.Trump dismissed the remarks as ""locker room talk"" and denied the subsequent accusations from more than 10 women who said he had groped them or made unwanted sexual advances.GLOOM OVER AMERICA

column1: Throughout his campaign - and especially in his Republican convention speech in July - Trump described a dark America that had been knocked to its knees by China
column2: Mexico
column3: Russia and Islamic State. The American dream was dead
column4: he said
column5: smothered by malevolent business interests and corrupt politicians
column6: and he said he alone could revive it.Trump said he would make America great again through the force of his personality
column7: negotiating skill and business acumen. He offered vague plans to win economic concessions from China
column8: to build a wall on the southern U.S. border to keep out undocumented immigrants and to make Mexico pay for it. He vowed to repeal Obamacare while being the ""greatest jobs president that God ever created"" and has proposed refusing entry to the United States of people from war-torn Middle Eastern nations
column9: a modified version of an earlier proposed ban on Muslims. Trump promoted himself as the ultimate success story. He dated beautiful women
column11: had his own television reality show and erected skyscrapers that bore his name in big gold letters. Everything in his life was the greatest
column16: even though critics assailed his experiences with bankruptcies
column17: the failures of his Atlantic City
column19: casinos and what they viewed as the misplaced pride he showed when presented with evidence he avoided paying taxes.Trump had flirted with presidential runs in the past and some initially saw his campaign as a vanity project meant to indulge his ego and burnish his brand. It was expected to be short-lived but as the election season progressed
column21: winning state nominating contests despite an unconventional campaign that relied on large-scale rallies and mostly ignored grass-roots work.His hired advisers came to realize there was only so much they could do to rein him in. His inner circle was dominated by his three oldest children - Donald Jr.

column1: TWEET ATTACKS
The rise of Trump
column2: once a registered Democrat
column3: threatened to blow up the Republican Party. Its establishment challenged his commitment to their tenets and organized against him. Prominent Republicans - including former presidents George H.W. Bush and George W. Bush and congressional leaders - shunned him or offered lukewarm support.Trump used Twitter as a weapon
column4: firing off insults and mockery at those who offended him
column5: including ""Crooked Hillary"" and Republican rivals ""Little Marco"" Rubio
column6: Jeb ""Low Energy"" Bush and ""Lyin' Ted"" Cruz.Another target was the family of a Muslim U.S. Army captain who died fighting in Iraq after the soldier's father had spoken against Trump at the Democratic National Convention. Trump sniped back for days despite advice to move on.As of late October
column7: the New York Times had counted 282 people and things he had insulted on Twitter since declaring his candidacy. The Trump candidacy was brimming with contradictions. The candidate who vowed to bring back jobs to the United States had his clothing line and campaign hats manufactured in foreign countries. The man who decried the corrupting power of money in politics boasted of having bought influence himself.Undocumented workers had been used on his building projects but as a candidate Trump vowed to ship illegal immigrants out of the country. He said no one respected women more than he did but even before the groping accusations emerged
column8: he was branded a misogynist for making fun of the appearance of rival candidate Carly Fiorina and an apparent reference to the menstrual cycle of Fox News' Megyn Kelly.

column1: YOU'RE FIRED!""
Trump's campaign trail demeanor seemed to draw from his experiences as host of ""The Apprentice
column2: a reality TV show where he barked a crowd-pleasing ""You're fired!"" at contestants who fell short in competitions.His speeches were often unscripted and featured boasts on everything from his money to his IQ. He peppered them with dubiously sourced declarations
column3: misperceptions and false statements.He suggested that gun rights activists could act to stop  Clinton from nominating liberal U.S. Supreme Court justices
column4: a remark the Clinton campaign called dangerous.Trump boasted of a fortune he put at $10 billion
column5: although in September Forbes magazine estimated it at $3.7 billion
column6: making him the 156th richest American.Trump regularly made comments that would have doomed a more conventional candidate
column7: such as when he said his supporters were so loyal that he could shoot someone on 5th Avenue in New York and not lose a single vote.In May he would draw accusations of racism for questioning the impartiality of a judge - born in the United States to Mexican immigrants - who was hearing a lawsuit against him.No other candidate referred to the size of his genitals during a debate. He was flattered when Russian President Vladimir Putin called him a ""brilliant and talented leader.""

column1: Trump mocked Senator John McCain
column2: the Republicans' presidential candidate in 2008
column3: for having been captured during the Vietnam War and said he wanted to punch a protester in the face at a Trump rally.

column1: DIFFICULT CHILD
Trump was born to money on June 14
column3: in the New York City borough of Queens
column4: the fourth of five children of Fred Trump
column5: who would become one of the city's biggest developers and landlords
column6: and his wife. It was Fred Trump who taught Donald the value of self-promotion and a killer instinct.By his own admission
column7: Trump was not an easy child and in the eighth grade his parents sent him to the New York Military Academy in hopes of instilling needed discipline. Through student and medical deferments during the Vietnam War
column8: Trump would never serve in the U.S. military but said the school gave him ""more training militarily than a lot of the guys that go into the military.""After graduating from the University of Pennsylvania
column9: Trump went to work for his father's company
column10: which focused on the outer New York City boroughs of Queens
column11: Brooklyn and Staten Island and owned an estimated 15
column12: 000 apartments. In 1973 the Trumps were charged with racial bias in their rental practices before reaching a settlement with the U.S. government.With a $1 million loan from his father
column13: Trump eventually went into business himself in Manhattan
column14: where he became a regular at some of the city's most exclusive clubs and developed a reputation as a ladies' man. TRUMP TOWER FLAGSHIP

column1: He soon made his mark with a series of real estate and development deals
column2: including redoing an old hotel at New York's Grand Central Terminal. In 1983 he opened his flagship
column3: 58-story Trump Tower
column4: which serves as both his primary residence and Trump Organization headquarters.More projects around the world would follow
column5: including golf courses
column6: the Mar-a-Lago private resort in Florida
column7: New York's venerable Plaza Hotel and casinos.Trump's projects had mixed success. The flops included the real estate-oriented Trump University
column8: Trump Mortgage
column9: Trump Airlines and Trump Vodka but it was his experience with four casinos in Atlantic City
column11: that took the golden luster off his empire. Timothy O'Brien
column12: author of ""TrumpNation: The Art of Being the Donald
column13: wrote that in the 1990s Trump was out of money and twice had to go to his siblings for loans. A former employee said the Trump Organization would have shut down if the family had not come through but Trump disputed that in his 1997 book ""Trump: The Art of the Comeback.""While he never filed for personal bankruptcy
column14: the downturn in the gaming industry sent parts of Trump's corporate empire to bankruptcy court in 1991
column17: the unsecured creditors received less than a penny on the dollar for their claim. Trump resigned as chairman four days before the filing. (Writing and reporting by Bill Trott in Washington; Additional reporting by Diane Craft; Editing by Howard Goller)"	['Trott'

column1: 9	9	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-court-garland-idUSKBN1310NM	Final reckoning approaches for Obama's high court nominee	"
By Lawrence Hurley
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON Several intriguing scenarios could unfold after Tuesday's U.S. election to break the deadlock over filling a Supreme Court vacancy that has provoked a bitter nine-month standoff between President Barack Obama and Senate Republicans.Obama nominated U.S. appeals court judge Merrick Garland on March 16 to replace long-serving conservative justice Antonin Scalia
column2: who died on Feb. 13. The Republican-led Senate
column3: in a move with little precedent
column4: has refused to consider the nomination
column5: saying the winner of the presidential election should make the pick.If Republican Donald Trump wins
column6: Garland's nomination would be dead. Trump has already put forth a list of conservative jurists as potential nominees.If Obama's fellow Democrat Hillary Clinton wins
column7: there are ways Garland could secure Senate confirmation to the lifetime post before Obama leaves office on Jan. 20.Senate Republican Leader Mitch McConnell has been adamant that Obama's successor should select Scalia's replacement and that he will not consider Garland's nomination during a post-election ""lame duck"" session.But McConnell could come under pressure by some Senate Republicans to allow confirmation hearings and a vote on Garland
column8: who has a reputation in Washington as a moderate
column9: out of fear Clinton could instead choose a more liberal nominee.The Senate's inaction on Garland has made the Supreme Court a potent issue in the election. After many years of leaning conservative
column10: a new Democratic appointment could tilt the court to the left for the first time in decades. Scalia's death left the court split with four liberals and four conservatives.

column1: 'NOT A CENTRIST'
Conservative activists dismiss the notion Garland is a moderate
column2: saying he would vote with the four liberal justices on major
column3: ideologically divisive issues.""Garland is a liberal
column4: not a centrist
column5: said Carrie Severino
column6: a lawyer with the Judicial Crisis Network.

column1: Liberal activists like Caroline Fredrickson
column2: president of the American Constitution Society
column3: said Republicans should move forward on Garland.""He's got every qualification you could ask for. He's exactly the type of judge they claimed they wanted
column4: Fredrickson said.If Democrats win control of the Senate in Tuesday's election
column5: the new congressional session would begin on Jan. 3
column6: and they could decide to move forward immediately on Garland's nomination before Obama's term ends. Clinton would play a major role by deciding whether or not she wanted to stick with Garland
column7: who was named to his current job by her husband Bill Clinton in 1997
column8: or choose her own nominee.""Chief Judge Garland is the most experienced nominee to the Supreme Court in our nation's history
column9: White House spokeswoman Brandi Hoffine said. It is time for Republicans to ""stop putting politics over the best interest of the country and do their job by giving the president's nominee to the Supreme Court a hearing and a vote

column1: Clinton has said Garland should be confirmed this year but has not committed to re-nominating him if she wins. Some Republicans have floated the idea of staunch opposition to any Clinton nominee
column2: raising the possibility of the seat remaining vacant long-term.McConnell has said no Obama nominee will be confirmed this year. There are no signs so far of Republican leaders backing off that position.Garland
column4: and other members of the Washington legal community joined the eight current justices inside the Supreme Court's ornate courtroom on Friday at an memorial event honoring Scalia
column5: four days before the election that will help decide his fate.There has been little controversy over Garland's suitability to sit on the Supreme Court as there has been with some past nominees. He is widely respected in the legal community and has won praise from Democrats and Republicans. (Reporting by Lawrence Hurley; Additional reporting by David Morgan and Richard Cowan; Editing by Will Dunham)"	['Obama'
